Utilities

DNA Constants

A.J. Vetturini

IDIG and MMBL

Carnegie Mellon University

This script contains the DNA constant values (e.g. bp rise)

class mango.utils.DNA_property_constants.BDNA(diameter: float = 2.25, pitch_per_rise: float = 0.34)[source]

pitch_per_rise: float = 0.34

Design IO

A.J. Vetturini

IDIG and MMBL

Carnegie Mellon University

This script is for reading in / outputting design files. For example, exporting to PLY file to convert a design to a DNA file via DAEDALUS2.

mango.utils.design_io.all_same(strings)[source]

Simple function to verify that the filename is unique when doing a mass export

mango.utils.design_io.export_DNA_design(automated_scaffold_executable_path: str, design: ~mango.design_spaces.polyhedral_design_space.PolyhedralSpace, export_path: str, savename_no_extension: str, DNA_geometry=<class 'mango.utils.DNA_property_constants.BDNA'>, scaffold_sequence_filepath: str | None = None) → int[source]

This is the top level function a user should call which will export a single design. The export_design_to_ply is called by this function.

Parameters:

  • design – PolyhedralSpace design space that is to be converted to a PLY file

  • automated_scaffold_executable_path – Filepath to automated algorithm (e.g. DAEDALUS2.exe path)

  • export_path – Filepath where to save the DNA design files to

  • savename_no_extension – User defined name to save the design as

  • DNA_geometry – Do not change

  • scaffold_sequence_filepath – Path to sequence file to use, default is M13

mango.utils.design_io.export_design_to_ply(design: PolyhedralSpace, savepath: str, savename_no_extension: str)[source]

NOT INTENDED FOR END USER USE. PLEASE SEE export_DNA_design for the user-facing function

This function exports a given PolyhedralSpace to a .ply file for the use in a automated scaffold routing algorithm

Parameters:

  • design – PolyhedralSpace design space that is to be converted to a PLY file

  • savepath – Filepath where to save the ply file

  • savename_no_extension – Filename of the ply file to use

Returns:

Directory path of where the file was saved

mango.utils.design_io.export_list_of_designs_to_ply(design_list: list, savepath: str, list_of_savenames_no_extensions: list)[source]

NOT INTENDED FOR END USER USE. PLEASE SEE mass_design_export for the user-facing function

This function will export a whole list of designs such that large amounts of data can be gathered.

Parameters:

  • design_list – List of PolyhedralSpace design space’s that are to be converted to PLY files

  • savepath – Filepath where to save the ply file

  • list_of_savenames_no_extensions – List of filenames to save the files as (should be length of design_list)

mango.utils.design_io.mass_design_export(automated_scaffold_executable_path: str, export_path: str, aj1_filepath: str, scaffold_sequence_filepath: str, DNA_geometry=<class 'mango.utils.DNA_property_constants.BDNA'>)[source]

This is the top level function a user should call which will export a single design. The export_design_to_ply is called by this function.

Parameters:

  • aj1_filepath – Filepath to .aj1 file that was exported from a multi-objective optimization process

  • automated_scaffold_executable_path – Filepath to automated algorithm (e.g. DAEDALUS2.exe path)

  • export_path – Filepath where to save the DNA design files to

  • DNA_geometry – Do not change

  • scaffold_sequence_filepath – Path to sequence file to use, default is M13

Math Functions

A.J. Vetturini

IDIG and MMBL

Carnegie Mellon University

These are various functions used throughout the application that range from mathematical functions to graph-based functions which return specific values from a provided graph. There are no custom data types used in any of these functions which is the criteria I used to “separate” out the code.

mango.utils.mango_math.all_node_xyz_dict(graph: Graph, nodes: list) → dict[source]

This function simply returns all nodes as a dictionary for design constraint checking

Parameters:

  • graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

  • nodes – List of all node index values [1, 2, 3, …]

Returns:

Dictionary mapping node index values to the node X Y Z value

mango.utils.mango_math.are_points_non_collinear(p1: array, p2: array, p3: array)[source]

JIT compiled function that determines if 3 points are all collinear

Parameters:

  • p1 – [X Y Z] value of a point in 3D space

  • p2 – [X Y Z] value of a point in 3D space

  • p3 – [X Y Z] value of a point in 3D space

Returns:

True if points are collinear, False if not

mango.utils.mango_math.calculate_design_edge_lengths(graph: Graph) → list[source]

Loop that calculate the total edge lengths of all edges in the design in units of nanometers

Parameters:

graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

Returns:

List of length values [23.23, 24.56, …] in units (nm)

mango.utils.mango_math.find_graph_differences(graph1: Graph, graph2: Graph)[source]

Function that determines any changes in the graph nodes / edges as well as any of the attributes between the nodes of the passed in graphs.

Parameters:

  • graph1 – design_graph before any design change was made

  • graph2 – design_graph after a grammar was applied to graph1

Returns:

Set of differences in nodes, edges, and attributes

mango.utils.mango_math.find_non_collinear_nodes(graph: Graph, node: int, potential_nodes: list) → tuple[source]

This function considers a graph, a node, and a list of potential nodes and determines which combination of the node and any two of the potential nodes results in a non-collinear set of three nodes. Otherwise, it return -1 -1 -1

Parameters:

  • graph – design_graph graph we are updating

  • node – Node index #

  • potential_nodes – List of potential node indices to check to find a non-collinear set of three

Returns:

Tuple of either 3 node indexes or (-1 -1 -1) signalling “no set found”

mango.utils.mango_math.find_shortest_path(graph: Graph, n1: int, n2: int) → list[source]

This function returns the shortest path between two nodes on the graph

Parameters:

  • graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

  • n1 – Index of node 1 stored in design_graph

  • n2 – Index of node 2 stored in design_graph

Returns:

List of length values [23.23, 24.56, …] in units (nm)

mango.utils.mango_math.find_smaller_z_value(graph: Graph, node1: int, node2: int) → array[source]

This function simply finds which of two nodes has a smaller Z value which is used in a fringe case of plotting.

Parameters:

  • graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

  • node1 – 1st node to check

  • node2 – 2nd node to check

mango.utils.mango_math.get_all_edges_in_graph(graph: Graph) → array[source]

This function just returns all edges found within a graph as a 2D NumPy array

Parameters:

graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

Returns:

NumPy array of all edges defined by the XYZ points [[[X1, Y1, Z1], [X2, Y2, Z2]], …]

mango.utils.mango_math.get_all_verts_in_graph(graph: Graph, vertex_mapping: dict) → array[source]

This function just returns all vertices found within a graph as a 2D NumPy array

Parameters:

  • graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

  • vertex_mapping – Dictionary of what vertex goes to which position in the graph.

Returns:

NumPy array of vertices

mango.utils.mango_math.intersecting_edge_calc(P1: array, P2: array, P3: array, P4: array) → array[source]

JIT compiled function that determines the distance between a set of points generated along the axes defined by P1 -> P2 and P3 -> P4. The goal of this function is to find the nearest distance between two lines in 3D space to determine if there is an intersection or not.

Parameters:

  • P1 – [X Y Z] value of a point in 3D space (used to defined axis P1 P2)

  • P2 – [X Y Z] value of a point in 3D space (used to defined axis P1 P2)

  • P3 – [X Y Z] value of a point in 3D space (used to defined axis P3 P4)

  • P4 – [X Y Z] value of a point in 3D space (used to defined axis P3 P4)

Returns:

Numpy array of all distances calculated

mango.utils.mango_math.length_and_direction_between_nodes(graph: Graph, node1: int, node2: int) → tuple[array, array][source]

This function calculates the distance between two nodes and returns that distance and the direction of the vector connected N1 -> N2

Parameters:

  • graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

  • node1 – Index of node 1 stored in design_graph

  • node2 – Index of node 2 stored in design_graph

Returns:

Tuple of (Magnitude / Length between nodes, vector [i, j, k] establishing direction

mango.utils.mango_math.node_from_xyz(graph: Graph, xyz: array) → int[source]

This function returns the node number of a specified X Y Z array from the passed in design graph

Parameters:

  • graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

  • xyz – NumPy array in form of [X, Y, Z] to return the node of

Returns:

Integer of node number represented by xyz

mango.utils.mango_math.nodes_on_same_face(all_faces: dict, n1: int, n2: int) → bool[source]

This function will take in two nodes and return TRUE if they ARE on the same face, and FALSE if not

Parameters:

  • all_faces – Dictionary of all faces contained in the design

  • n1 – 1st node to check

  • n2 – 2nd node to check

Returns:

True: Nodes on same face; False: Nodes NOT on same face.

mango.utils.mango_math.parallelepiped_volume(cell_type: str, a: float, b: float, c: float, alpha: float, beta: float, gamma: float) → float[source]

This function simply calculates the volume of a parallelepiped but changes depending on the cell_type attribute as the volume can be more readily calculated through the equations below.

mango.utils.mango_math.positive_value(x: float) → bool[source]
mango.utils.mango_math.rotation_matrix_from_vectors(vec1: array, vec2: array) → array[source]

Calculates the rotation matrix defined by two vectors.

If you ever find yourself doing tons of matrix stuff: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotation_matrix

Parameters:

  • vec1 – Vector one defined by [X Y Z]

  • vec2 – Vector two defined by [X Y Z]

Returns:

2D NumPy array of the rotation_matrix found

mango.utils.mango_math.sign(num)[source]
mango.utils.mango_math.unit_vector(P1: array, P2: array)[source]

Calculate the unit vector betewen two points

mango.utils.mango_math.update_nodal_position(graph: Graph, node: int, new_xyz: array, numDecimals: int) → None[source]

This function will take a node and it’s new XYZ positions and update the NetworkX graph to represent this. NOTE: This does NOT update the values in the triangular faces, another function controls this.

Parameters:

  • graph – design_graph graph we are updating

  • node – Node index #

  • new_xyz – New XYZ Positions [0:X, 1:Y, 2:Z]

  • numDecimals – Number of decimals to round values to

Returns:

Nothing, just updates the design graph:

mango.utils.mango_math.update_vertex_in_all_faces(all_faces: dict, node: int, new_xyz: array) → None[source]

This function updates the attribute values in stored MeshFace objects

mango.utils.mango_math.xyz_from_graph(graph: Graph, node: int) → array[source]

This function returns the X Y Z value of a specified node # from the design_graph

Parameters:

  • graph – NetworkX undirected graph which is stored as the design_graph object

  • node – Node # to return the X Y Z location of
